thread.title: Is this the plane of the future? Stunning 'blended wing' design with hydrogen-powered engines revealed by KLM could mean non-stop flights from the UK to Australia (but you'll have to wait until 2050)
thread.title_full: Is this the plane of the future? Stunning 'blended wing' design with hydrogen-powered engines revealed by KLM could mean non-stop flights from the UK to Australia (but you'll have to wait until 2050) | Daily Mail Online

author: John Hutchinson for MailOnline
title: Is this the plane of the future? Stunning 'blended wing' design with hydrogen-powered engines revealed by KLM could mean non-stop flights from the UK to Australia (but you'll have to wait until 2050)
text:
662 shares 161
View
comments
Non-stop flights from Europe to Australia could become a reality thanks to a stunning 'blended-wing' plane design with hybrid engines that drastically lowers fuel consumption.
Dutch airline KLM has teamed up with Delft University of Technology to produce concept designs that could be the future of planes.
The main feature is a wing design that will ensure better fuel efficiency due to the aircraft being more streamlined.
Is this the plane of the future? A blended wing design would mean better fuel management enabling direct flights from Europe to Australia
The AHEAD aircraft, which stands for Advanced Hybrid Engine Aircraft Development, is being designed to carry 300 passengers over a range of 8,700 miles – which would put the UK within striking distance of .
Writing on the company's blog, KLM engineer Rob Duivis says: 'A blended wing body is one of the very promising designs to minimise the drag and, is so doing, making aircraft much more fuel-efficient.'
 Disgruntled mothers up in arms after Coventry hotel sign... Violent stomach bug sweeps through four-star Tenerife... Would you pay £57 for ten chocolates, £25 for a bottle of... Flaming craters, ice tunnels and hot springs filled with... 662 shares Another key feature are the two hybrid engines, which make the plane much greener.
The first burns either cryogenic hydrogen or liquefied natural gas (LNG), and the second burns either kerosene or biofuel, thus reducing emissions into the atmosphere.
While KLM bosses insist the innovative design could well be the future, it is still some way off
This is instead of turbofan engines, where heated air powers turbines.
'By using two different combustor and fuel systems, the engine's total efficiency increases and emissions are reduced,' added Duivis.
But don't get excited just yet, as KLM's concept is a long way from becoming reality.
'The AHEAD design is a long-term study, with many aspects yet to be researched,' said Duivis.
'The timeframe for introduction of an aircraft of this type is expected to appear sometime around 2050.'
Blended wing body concept by Cranfield University (related)
